# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import plotly.offline as py
import plotly.graph_objs as go
import plotly
plotly.offline.init_notebook_mode(connected=True)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session

                           hover_name="state",
                           zoom=11, height=300)

ax = df.groupby('state')['NUMSPEC'].mean().sort_values(ascending=True).plot(kind='barh', figsize=(12,8),
                                                                                   title='Mean Number of Species by States')
plt.xlabel('Count')
plt.ylabel('States')
plt.show()
source.366a90a6:
g = sns.lmplot(x="LON_DD", y="LAT_DD", data=df,
           fit_reg=False, scatter_kws={"s": 30}, hue='state', height=10)
plt.title('Endangered Fish by States')
plt.show()
source.6a27b10e:
##Code by Taha07  https://www.kaggle.com/taha07/data-scientists-jobs-analysis-visualization/notebook

from wordcloud import WordCloud
from wordcloud import STOPWORDS
stopwords = set(STOPWORDS)
wordcloud = WordCloud(background_color = 'Green',
                      height =2000,
                      width = 2000
                     ).generate(str(df["Common_Name"]))
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (12,12)
plt.axis("off")
plt.imshow(wordcloud)
plt.title("Species Common Names")
plt.show()

                     ).generate(str(df["GENUS"]))

source.5db047b9:
plt.figure(figsize=(20,12))
g = sns.scatterplot(x='LON_DD', y='LAT_DD', data=df, hue='HUCName')
g.legend(loc='center left', bbox_to_anchor=(1.25, 0.5), ncol=1);
#this annotate has been copy from this stackoverflow page
#https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39147492/annotate-seaborn-factorplot
plt.annotate('Kanawha', xy=(-79.980100, 38.326069), xytext=(-79.980100, 38.326069),
             arrowprops=dict(facecolor='red', shrink=0.05, headwidth=8))
plt.annotate('Potomac', xy=(-78.476200, 39.286894), xytext=(-78.476200, 39.286894),
             arrowprops=dict(facecolor='red', shrink=0.05, headwidth=8))
plt.show()
source.cede8288:
# graph
import networkx as nx
from pyvis.network import Network
source.e672c642:
# create graph from edges
state= df["state"].value_counts()

G = nx.from_pandas_edgelist(df, 'state', 'GENUS', create_using=nx.DiGraph())
# and plot
nx.draw(G, with_labels=True, node_size=1000, alpha=0.5, arrows=True)
plt.title('States ' + str(state) + ' Genus')
plt.show()
source.edf23564:
# create graph from edges
GENUS = df['GENUS'].value_counts()[:10]

G = nx.from_pandas_edgelist(df, 'state', 'GENUS', create_using=nx.DiGraph())

# and plot
nx.draw(G, with_labels=True, node_size=1000, alpha=0.5, arrows=True)
plt.title('Fish Genus ' + str(GENUS))
plt.show()
source.bfc677fb:
# create graph from edges
species = df["species"].value_counts()[:10]

G = nx.from_pandas_edgelist(df, 'state', 'GENUS', create_using=nx.DiGraph())

# and plot
nx.draw_circular(G, with_labels=True, node_size=1000, alpha=0.5, arrows=True)
plt.title('Bidirectional view of species ' + str(species))
plt.show()
source.6c23252f:
net = Network(notebook=True, width='800px', height='500px')
net.directed = True
net.from_nx(G)
net.show('example.html')
source.d29faf38:
# plot in log scale
plt.hist(np.log10(1+f_counts.Frequency),100)
plt.yscale('log')
plt.grid()
plt.title('Distribution of Endangered Fish Species count')
plt.xlabel('log10(1+counts)')
plt.show()
